campaign.story:
“Soon, the Here bud may be a big part of how we interact with the world.” - .mic
“Two wireless earbuds and a smartphone app may soon change the way we hear our favorite bands and concerts.” - Rolling Stone
“The world sounds a lot nicer with Here in my ears .” - Wired
HERE IS A WIRELESS INTERACTIVE LISTENING SYSTEM
Through two truly wireless, in-ear buds and a smartphone app, Here allows you to instantly control real world audio so you can hear what you want to hear - no matter the situation - and be fully immersed in your audio environment.
Here does not stream or play recorded music. Instead, the Digital Signal Processor (DSP) inside Here acts as a studio in your ears by providing you with a volume knob, equalizer and effects to transform real world audio. Use this “remote control for your ears” to have an optimal listening experience every time.
HERE PROVIDES AUDIO CURATION TOOLS FOR EVERY LIVE ENVIRONMENT
Here has been engineered to give you control of any and all live listening experiences: Suppress the jet engine on an airplane. Reduce a baby crying. Boost the bass at a club. Live mix a concert by adding reverb. Enhance your senses and personalize every listening experience.
  THE TECH
The technology used in Here is fundamentally different from any audio technology that has come before it. Here uses a variety of signal processing algorithms that target specific frequency ranges to modify sound as it enters your ears. Each Here bud captures incoming sound waves, processes the audio, and then plays back the desired result with no perceivable latency (i.e. in under 30 microseconds). 
HERE LISTENING (SIMULATED)
Although nothing compares to actually experiencing the live curation provided by the Here system, we’ve put together a clip (an original track by our very own graphic designer, Geoff Lynn of the Newcomers Club) that simulates some of its functions.
The track below illustrates how a few features that will be available in the Here app—Bass Boost, Treble Boost, Reverb, and Flange—are intended to sound when you use the Here Active Listening System:
THE FIRST TRUE HEARABLE
Here is not meant to replace your headphones, headsets, or earbuds. The Here Active Listening System is designed for live listening environments, and is optimized for targeted, episodic use in live scenarios (e.g. concerts, stadiums, flights) where you can control and curate what’s happening in real time. Put simply, earbuds are for listening to recorded audio. Here buds are for engaging with real world sound.
CURATE LIVE MUSIC AND CREATE YOUR OWN SONIC WORLD
The Here system has been optimized for live music, so we invited two of the world's top violinists to our NY office to put it to the test. Watch Charles Yang and Tessa Lark demo an early Here prototype and experiment with live EQ:
HANS AND HERE
Hans Zimmer, legendary film composer and music producer, has been an invaluable partner in helping us ensure that Here’s functionality is optimized for live music listening. Watch below as he explores an early Here prototype and talks about the future of sound, music listening, technology, and the vast potential of what Here could mean for the future of how we hear the world:
DESIGN
Given that it's the first product of its kind, Here presented a unique challenge for our design team. We wanted to create a wearable that you would be proud to wear - something that was both functional and elegant. To achieve this, we developed a product architecture that optimizes battery power and efficiency, while being discreet enough to allow you to bae yourself in social settings.
The simple shape of the Here buds masks the complexity of its many components. It took us months to figure out how to fit so much tech into a small form factor that sits comfortably and securely within the ear. The inner shape of the Here buds is the result of countless iterations and prototypes, tested and evaluated hundreds of times. To further optimize comfort and performance, Here has three interchangeable sizes of custom designed silicone tips.
ENGINEERING PROCESS
Here is redefining the limits of low-power signal processing and in-ear audio computing. We’ve chosen a comprehensive combination of hardware components and features for optimal live audio processing (and listening): a low power ARM processor for effects and EQ calculations, an ultra low latency audio input/output system, and a Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) radio for control via smart phone. Our premium low-noise MEMS microphones handle massive SPL, while the powerful driver can add or subtract wide-band audio so that you can tailor your sound experience in even the loudest of acoustic environments. 
On the mechanical side, we carefully selected materials and engineered complex internal air spaces to allow for maximum sound reduction, targeted signal processing and deep bass. We ran tests in simulation on our boards and on our early “Franken-Here” models (see below) to ensure the highest quality performance. 
TESTING
After countless months of testing the Here system in our lab, Jacob (our Director of Design) and Andrew (Senior Product Engineer) went undercover with an early working prototype to try out the Here buds during our partnership activation at Coachella 2015. It was important for us to make sure that Here worked in a loud, real world music setting, and we couldn't think of a better environment than Coachella. Check it out!
THE DOPPLER LABS VISION: IMMERSIVE WEARABLE TECHNOLOGY
At Doppler Labs, we believe in a post-mobile future where tech gets out of the way of the human experience. We believe wearable technology should integrate seamlessly into our lives and enable us to curate our environment to our liking. In service of that vision, we build products that give you the tools to engage with the world around you without removing you from the moment or experience.
The Here Active Listening System is the first step in pursuing that vision. We wanted to provide the best sound quality at shows, remove unwanted noise, and fix sleepless overnight flights, so we created an elegant solution to give you control of your audio environment.
As our technology becomes more powerful with each iteration (and each additional user), we open up doors for future innovation. The possibilities of what we can do with a speaker, microphone, and computer in your ear are limitless, from using voice as an input modality and speech as an output modality to transforming the fundamentals of human communication.
WHERE WE'VE BEEN: DUBS ACOUSTIC FILTERS
We launched DUBS Acoustic Filters in September 2014 and since then have sold hundreds of thousands of DUBS, won several design awards, and most importantly have gained the praise of audiophiles around the world, with some even claiming that the DUBS Acoustic Filters were "the best thing I bought this year".
By creating the DUBS, we were able to gain valuable experience. We assembled a team with proven expertise in launching new products, forged partnerships across the music space (e.g. Coachella, Tao Group, SoulCycle, Bonnaroo/Outside Lands, AM Only, Tiesto, Hans Zimmer, Quincy Jones), learned valuable information about our ears (their shape and how they perceive sound), and worked out the kinks of manufacturing products in China.
This experience has proven invaluable to the development of our team as we begin to ramp up for production of the Here Active Listening System. Given our track record, we are highly confident in our ability to deliver a great product and deliver it in the projected timeframe.
MEET THE HERE TEAM
Our confidence in our vision is founded in the expertise of our highly experienced team of designers, engineers, technologists and business leaders.
Doppler Labs is dedicated to our vision of enhancing all aspects of the listening experience by building immersive wearable technology. Each team member plays a critical role in helping us achieve our vision, drawing on their own personal experience building and shipping products for major tech companies like Apple, Amazon, Google and Microsoft, and disruptive start-ups like ClassPass, Dropbox, Palantir, Sonos, and Tesla (via Interlink Electronics).
We are launching the Here Active Listening System on Kickstarter because we believe in cultivating a community who can contribute to the development of Here. Through Kickstarter we are able to reach the most forward-thinking, passionate people who can provide us with valuable feedback that will help make our product great. Launching a new technology is hard. And we can use all the help we can get.
So if you are interested in music, sound, wearables, the future of hearing, bionics or computing, join us in the movement to optimize the way we experience real world audio, and help us change the way we all hear the world. 
Are you a software developer?
Join us in making Here more than just a product. If you are a developer, we would love your help in growing the Here system into a platform for your ears.  
For priority access to our forthcoming developer platform and first tier support from the Doppler Labs team, be sure to choose one of the two developer package options when selecting your reward.
Are you a producer, musician, or artist?
We want Here to redefine the way we listen to live music. As music lovers ourselves, we have optimized the Here system for live music and surrounded ourselves with some of the foremost composers and producers in the world.
Our team at Doppler Labs has made huge strides but we can only get better with the input of sound designers, engineers, producers and musicians. Choose our producers package or sign up to get involved and stay up to date.
EXPECTED DELIVERY
We expect to deliver Here to you in December 2015. We have calculated this date based on years of manufacturing experience. Your Here t-shirt and limited-edition numbered Here prints will be delivered to you by August 2015. If you’re a developer, we plan to ship your DVT pair in late October. All deliveries to US addresses will be completed free of charge. Backers shipping to addresses outside of the US should add $30 to their pledge amount for shipping.
REWARDS
WARRANTY
Each pair of Here buds comes with a 30-day (after we ship it) money-back guarantee and a 1-year limited warranty. You can find more information on our Return and Warranty Policy page.
PRIVACY POLICY
Our privacy policy can be found here.
CONTACT US
Questions? Shoot us an email at support@dopplerlabs.com.
Something else you're wondering about? Contact us.
SPECS 
Fit Style: In the ear 
Driver Size: 8mm 
Frequency Response: 20 - 20,000 Hz 
Cable Type: None 
Microphone: MEMS omni-directional 
Output: Peak SPL TBA (starting at ~100dB) 
Bluetooth: Bluetooth Low Energy 4.0 
Battery: Lithium ion rechargeable battery, 4-6 hours depending on usage
Weight: 9.5 - 10g 
Compatibility: Any iOS or Android device that supports BLE (Android 4.4 and up)
COMPONENT LAYOUT
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Here is a completely new technology and as with any product manufactured for the first time there is a possibility that unforeseen bugs, challenges and delays will occur.
 
That being said, we have already completed most of the design and engineering for the Here system and have a fully working prototype which we have tested with close partners, friends, and colleagues. 

We have identified our suppliers and CM and have already started planning production timelines and processes. Moreover, through the executional success we've had with DUBS, we have proven our ability to deliver hundreds of thousands of great quality products in short timeframes.

As we prepare to scale production, we continue to optimize our digital processing systems and maximize every inch of component space to bring you the best version of Here possible.

We pride ourselves on over-delivering and on relentless execution. Even after this Kickstarter project ends, we plan to send out continuous updates and announcements regarding Here (and beyond!).
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Why would the product stop working after only a half dozen recharges? If this is a common issue, let me know.

Just another reminder why it doesn't pay to be an early adopter on Kickstarter. Here Active is proof positive that we were all foolish to take the bait for a half baked product. We would have all been better off for Doppler to get VC/Angel funding and buy the Here One when it hits the market, although the space is about to get a lot more crowded with large scale, well funded companies - e.g., Apple and Samsung - that will make the future for fringe companies like Doppler dim. campaign.story:
So many possibilities! Makes an amazing holiday season gift!
Incorporate Build Upons into the latest Star Wars spaceships!
 We are Lunchbox Electronics and we are creating Build Upons: Light up bricks to build upon your existing LEGO® creations.  Light up your robot, house, or spaceship! Our Build Upons are based on the smallest 1x1 brick we could fit an LED into to create elegant and flexible designs. The Build Upons system has three types of bricks: an LED brick, a power brick, and a bridge brick. 
You can power an LED brick by stacking it directly on top of a power brick, or use the bridge brick to route power to LEDs throughout your design, allowing LEDs to be placed anywhere! 
This 3D printed prototype shows an LED brick stacked on a bridge brick stacked on a power brick.
The bridge bricks allow for flexibility within the design. The below examples use the bridge bricks to route power from the battery pack to the LED bricks, wherever the LED bricks happen to be. The bridge bricks function even when turned 90 degrees!
Build a Helicopter!
These are only a few of the projects that highlight our bricks, we can't wait to see what you do!
We have created these prototype bricks, but we need you to get to a production run!
                                                         Specs and Process
This product will be released as open source hardware upon shipping! Trust us - Alicia wrote the book on it.
We are using standard surface mount white LEDs in the bricks powered by a 4.5v battery pack. AA batteries not included. The bricks have metal running through the top and bottom creating connections where they stack. We have gone through several prototyped designs, improving each one. 
Here is a walk through of our design changes in R&D.
Each iteration reflects a change to make our product more manufacturable and easy to assemble. We are now in our fourth major design iteration and ready for production. The earliest prototype was done with 3D printing, copper tape, and inserting LEDs into a plastic brick by hand, which was time consuming and tedious. In order to build lots of these bricks we need to invest in injection molding. 
The Team
This was the only photo that Puppet had her eyes open.
 *Alicia Gibb* Alicia Gibb is the CEO of Lunchbox Electronics. She has been playing with LEGO® her whole life, but started research on lighting them up in 2007. Alicia has a Masters in Information Science, focusing on physical computing and interaction design. She is also the founder and Executive Director of the Open Source Hardware Association (OSHWA), an organization to educate and promote building and using open source hardware and wrote Building Open Source Hardware. She is a member of NYCResistor, founded and co-chaired two Open Hardware Summits and directs the Blow Things Up Lab at University of Colorado Boulder. Her work has appeared in Wired magazine, IEEE Spectrum, Hackaday and the New York Times. 
*Jason Brownstein* Jason Brownstein is the Mechanical Engineer of Lunchbox Electronics. He has also been playing with LEGO® his entire life! He graduated from the University of Colorado Boulder with a Masters in Mechanical Engineering. Jason has prior experience with product design, manufacturing, and design and fabrication of interactive art. Building things to withstand all human conditions is his jam. On any given day you can find him playing with the 3D printer, on the phone with manufacturers, making 3D models, or cuddling baby bunnies.
*Puppet* Puppet is the Marketing Director and Customer Service at Lunchbox Electronics. She has been doing comedic relief all her life. Puppet has an honorary PhD in Antics and Tomfoolery. Talking in a high pitched voice is what she does best. She is also Jason's boss when Alicia is out. 
*Our Networks* Our team spreads farther than just who sits in the office everyday. We leverage advice and learn from notable figureheads within the hardware and electronics communities including Nathan Seidle of Sparkfun Electronics, Eric Schweikardt of Modular Robotics, Amanda Williams of Fabule Fabrications, Kipp Bradford of KippKitts, our friends at Sketching in Hardware, and all the friends at NCYResistor.
Help Us Spread the Word!
Every tweet and share will help us reach our goal and go above and beyond! 
Timeline
We are set up to begin manufacturing. We've gone through several iterations and prototypes already and are confident that we are ready to mass produce this product. We aim to have the kits out by Christmas 2015! These will be the prefect gift for LEGO® aficionados!
Lunchbox Electronics Timeline
2012 - First prototype designed!
2013 - Nesting design completely changed to the the Basket design
2014 - Copper design changed to incorporate 90 degree turns
2014 - Build Upons PTH (plated through-hole) version manufactured. Designed for use in printed circuit boards but also compatible with LEGO®. Fit and feel has been proven to be perfect!
2015 - Ready to begin manufacturing of Build Upons
When we ship the project's source will be released as open source hardware! 
Budget
We have already done the R&D to get through the initial prototyping costs: 3D printing, PCBs, and an initial proof of concept for tooling. We will be using multiple sets of tooling including die casting and injection molding to achieve the finished product. We are planning to cover the non-reoccuring project costs with our Kickstarter as injection molding is the most expensive part of our project.
Help Us Spread the Word!
Every tweet and share will help us reach our goal and go above and beyond!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The risks and challenges of any hardware project is in the manufacturing. We already have manufacturers lined up for this product who specialize in precision manufacturing and are confident they can achieve the tolerances needed for a good fit. There are often delays with hardware, but we believe we've found manufacturers who are prepared to create our designs and work through changes quickly and effectively. They are responsive to our design changes, give great feedback and work well with us. We have already manufactured a less complicated through-hole LED brick as a trial run: http://www.lunchboxelectronics.com/product/build-upons-pth-edition. Manufacturing the previous brick allowed us to prove that we could create interlocking bricks compatible with LEGO®. Our current challenges are the cost of injection molding and die casting, but that's where you come in! 

LEGO® is a trademark of the LEGO® Group, which does not sponsor, authorize or endorse this project or web site.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hi Friends of Lunchbox Electronics and Build Upons,
We can’t give you enough high fives for supporting our first Kickstarter. Although we made a third of our goal we learned a lot and with this new knowledge, we can afford to create a limited run of Build Upons at a $30,000 goal.
So here is the deal, the original goal of $90,000 was for production tooling (creating our LED bricks in greater numbers). With a goal of $30,000 we can create the LED Build Upons at the prototype tooling cost. To be clear we won’t lose quality of the bricks we just can’t make them in larger quantities.

campaign.story:
SmartScope
The SmartScope combines 3 high-end instruments into 1 mobile, smart device. Accessible previously only to high-tech labs, the SmartScope allows everyone to own a personal lab!
Starring a dual-channel 100MS/s oscilloscope, the SmartScope is the world's first lab instrument which works on both PC, laptop, tablet and smartphone. This is a must-have for any maker, and for anybody involved in hardware development!
Rewards
Recent Press
Tech Marinade: “Smart All-In-One Tool For Makers”
The Mac Observer: “Want to Turn Your iPad or iPhone into an Oscilloscope?”
Geeky Gadgets: “100MS/s Open Source SmartScope Oscilloscope For Your Tablet” 
OpenElectronics: “SmartScope is reinventing the oscilloscope in Open Source”
Stretch Goals
Key Product Highlights
2x100MS/s 45MHz Oscilloscope
50MS/s Arbitrary Waveform Generator
Digital logic analyzer at 100MS/s
Digital waveform generator at 100MS/s
200 waveforms/second data updates
Demo movie
Make sure to check out this movie, where we show the current status of the SmartScope:
PLAY

Open source
By giving full access to the framework of the SmartScope, a whole new dimension of possibilities is opening up. In its most basic form, this open framework allows you to hook up your creation to the extension ports of the SmartScope and control it from your PC or smartphone.
When you're taking on more advanced projects, you'll appreciate the full access you have to the powerful FPGA. The framework is based on FPGA registers which you can control from the PC or tablet, giving you full control over your FPGA from the first moment you're starting. Even more, since you can flash the FPGA through the USB controller, you don't need to invest in expensive programmers!
Even more advanced projects can make use of the full-speed bi-directional data transfer capabilities, transferring data to or from your device.
Initially, all source files of the full framework will be presented as a git repository, together with additional repositories focusing on extremely simple samples, showing how to start developing for each of the components of the SmartScope. This will hopefully create community branches, which will be added to our community site.
Why do you need a SmartScope?
An oscilloscope is the basic measurement device for anyone involved in hardware tinkering: it allows you to see how the voltage behaves at any point in your design, at any moment in time. Much like a breakpoint in software, which allows you to verify the value of all variables at a certain moment in time. The SmartScope should be the tool to optimize the debugging and development of your project.
SmartScope should appeal to:
Arduino, Raspberry Pi & DIY enthusiasts: having access to an oscilloscope will greatly reduce your debugging time, as now you can literally see what's happening.
Makers: using the open-source framework, you can use the SmartScope to control your inventions from your smartphone!
Students & Teachers: combining an oscilloscope, AWG and logic analyzer into a single mobile device makes the SmartScope a great addition to any student lab desk. Its open-source framework can serve both as example, as well as starting place for your code. You're encouraged to publish working projects on our community page at www.lab-nation.com!
Professional hardware engineers: even though this page is strongly aimed towards makers and hardware enthusiast, the SmartScope was born from an analysis of what performance is required to visualize any job but the extreme high-end -- such as DDR or RF implementations. Therefore, we're sure that any electronics engineer will appreciate the combination of performance and versatility offered by the SmartScope.
Compatibility - Cross Platform
We're proud to announce that the SmartScope is the world's first instrument to work on iOS, Android, Windows, Linux and OSX! This true cross-platform-compatibility was achieved by choosing for the Xamarin framework from the very beginning of UI development. As a result, the SmartScope works on virtually all PCs, laptops, tablets and smartphones.
Graphical User Interface
On all existing USB oscilloscopes, the software clearly has been an afterthought. Not so for the SmartScope! While competitors try to imitate traditional scopes by literally demanding the user to rotate knobs with a mouse, the SmartScope reinvents the way we will operate oscilloscopes: by making full use of the touchscreen!
The PC software is identical to the mobile version. With intuitive operations (scroll to zoom or simply drag a rectangle, dragging to reposition) and innovative features (window pops to foreground on trigger) it's our mission to continually provide you with the software you need to aid your projects.
Why is the cost so low?
It's LabNation's vision to open up the market of professional electronics measurement equipment to everyone. At $179 we believe there's no one out there offering a comparable scope. If you add the AWG, logic analyzer capabilities, intuitive software AND pioneering Android/iOS support, it is clear that the price could have been far higher. 
By giving everyone access to a quality development and debugging instrument, we hope to contribute to the increasing speed at which amazing projects are making the transition from ideas to prototypes!
Will the SmartScope work on my smartphone/tablet?
The SmartScope is the world's first instrument targeting compatibility with both iOS and Android. Although the required functionality (USB-OTG) is becoming a standard for Android devices the past few years, we were not able to get cooperation from Apple (yet ;). As such, our team set out to start from jailbroken iOS devices, and hack our way to the USB controller, which we eventually succeeded in. However, this means the SmartScope will only be recognized in case you apply a jailbreak patch to your iOS smartphone (which is a free, legal software operation that takes 10 minutes of your time). 
On Android, USB-OTG is supported since Android v3.1, however it depends on the age and quality of your phone whether USB-OTG was implemented correctly. There are sites describing how to check for USB-OTG functionality, in case you want to be sure.
More specifically:
Windows: driver available for XP, Win7, Win8
OSX: supported, no driver needed (uses generic USB driver)
Linux: supported, no driver needed (uses generic USB driver)
Android: tested and verified on $52 Q88 tablet, Sony Xperia Z. More will be tested soon, but no problems expected as phones/tablets either support USB openly or not.
iOS: requires 5-minute legal software jailbreak patch. Tested and verified on iPad1, iPad2, iPhone 5, iPhone 5S. Will not work on iPhones 1,2,3 as they simply don't have a USB chip.
Power/Sync port
The Power/Sync port is nothing more than a microUSB port, whose purpose is twofold:
In case your tablet/smartphone is running low on battery, you can power the SmartScope through this port. This can be done using any standard microUSB charger cable.
More advanced, we have foreseen the possibility to connect multiple SmartScopes together. In such case, synchronisation between the different SmartScopes is essential. This can be achieved easily by connecting both devices through their Power/Sync port using the cable provided in the 4-channel reward package.
Specifications
LabNation team
Key members at January 2014:
Riemer Grootjans: Ex-whiz-kid Riemer always believed he would be a game developer, until his master thesis convinced him of the beauty of electronics. After going for a PhD on real-time 3D cameras, he co-founded a company designing 3D cameras now distributed by several major California-based companies. As such, he had the rare opportunity to lead a hardware patent from prototype to mass-production. At the same time, he created the largest site with tutorials on XNA, reaching more than 7000 daily pageviews and 2000 registered community members. Additionally, Riemer authored 3 books on XNA with positive reviews. He received the Microsoft MVP award in 2007, 2008, 2009 and 2010. 
Prof. Maarten Kuijk: Maarten is the live version of Wikipedia of Electronics. His research project have resulted in two spin-offs which have grown to a total of 120 employees, of which one has recently been acquired by Microchip in November 2013. Nevertheless, he stays true to his passion: teaching parttime classes as Professor to Master students in Electronical Engineering at the University of Brussels. Maarten acts as mentor to the SmartScope project. 
Glan Li: Born and educated in China, Glan was intrigued by the fundamental beauty of electronics. After finishing his Master in Electronical Engineering and working on various electronical projects, Glan was given responsability over a production line assembling more than 1 million camera devices per month. As such, he carries a wealth of experience in the areas of manufacturing and quality assurance.
Bruno Buyssens: After obtaining a Master in Business Engineering, Bruno pursued several technical jobs before refocusing towards marketing. He joined Sony and quickly moved towards Key Account Manager, dealing with distributors on a daily basis. Next to that, Bruno is well-known in the entrepreneurial scene, constantly looking for new business ideas and eager to launch his own start-up. With LabNation, he is looking forward to take a more leading role.
Where we are today
After about a year of research and development, we produced the first prototype in March 2013, a second version in August and third one in October. In November a small batch of 10 final products was produced in China under Glan's approving eye.
Thanks to the early production of 10 fully operational SmartScopes we now can say that everything is in place to start up full production -- what we're missing at this point is your strong backing to put the SmartScope into production. Software is feature-complete and validated to stream data on all platforms, while we keep developing to bring it closer to a first distributable version.  
Production Plan  
We didn't want to launch our Kickstarter before having a fully working and validated product. This took us more than a year and 3 iterations, but at this moment we have produced 10 fully functioning SmartScopes, meaning the SmartScope is ready to put into production.
However, we are planning one additional iteration after the end of our campaign: this allows us to include the best and most interesting ideas coming from your comments. After all, who knows how far possible stretch goals could take us? :)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
When bringing a hardware product from idea to reality, it is easy to think about what the product should and shouldn't do. However, when it comes to manufacturing, there are many more things to take into account: suppliers, reliability tests, calibration, production and certification all require experience and dedication.Therefore, it is no surprise that many hardware projects are facing delays, especially in the later phases of production. Here are the main root causes of such delays, and how we are preventing them:

- Need for more iterations. 
Many projects launch their Kickstarter campaign based on a first working prototype. Not so for the SmartScope: we are showing you fully functional and validated prototypes, which took us 3 iterations.

- Link with the Factory.
We are happy to have Glan in our team with who we have been working for several years, bringing us the invaluable manufacturing experience. 

- Certification
Before you can ship out products,, it is legally required to go through a full list of challenging certifications. We are lucky yo have specialists in our team that have taken the lead in the whole certification process of USB devices.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: All Kickstarter SmartScopes have been shipped!
updates.update_content:
We have some great news for you. Due to a fortunate speedup in the schedule of our manufacturer, last week we received all SmartScopes! We were happy to spend the weekend packaging all non-US orders, including the extra cables and invoices. The past 3 days, more than 750 packages have been picked up by the postal service, so you can expect a tracking number in your mailbox any moment now!
Together with all US orders SmartScopes crossing the Atlantic at this very moment, this means we have sent out all SmartScopes to our Kickstarter backers! Christopher (one of our Aussie backers) already mentioned his SmartScope took only 4 days to get to him, which seen from our location is pretty much on the other side of the globe. Do note that it will take a bit longer for the US SmartScopes to arrive.

It's a big day in the land of the SmartScope. This morning we moved a truckload of boxes - one thousand SmartScopes! - to be shipped off to the US, and the releasing of the software has taken a major step forward: for all but one platform, the software can be downloaded from our website or the Google Play store. 
Currently shipping!

After plenty of testing and development, we finally reached the point where we feel ready to present you our app for Android!
There are a bunch of differences between a computer environment and a mobile app environment. The most crucial ones had been validated before we launched our Kickstarter campaign. Yet, the number of tasks to finish in order to get to a similar experience on PC and tablet was countless. But in the end, we made it.

Even though this week's update is rather brief as the achievements have been mainly under the hood, we would like to give you a short overview.  
Casings  
As promised by our Chinese supplier, they finished their new batch by Oct 11th, so all new casings were packaged and shipped by Oct 16th. They will arrive in Romania any day now.
Production

We just returned from our trip to Romania, but before recovering we thought it would be a good idea to provide you with a short update on how production is going.  
When we set out for Romania, we couldn't help feeling some notion of stress -- our production site had been changed from Belgium to Romania, and the first 500 units had already been soldered. Even the smallest mistake would mean days of reworks. Luckily, the first contacts with our Romanian colleagues proved to be professional yet genuinely friendly, and as it turned out the next day, they had done an extremely good job at producing the first 500 units!

The first 100 SmartScopes have been sent out quite some time ago, and we’re excited to see the first comments appear in our forum! We appreciate your early feedback, and will take all suggestions into account during our following software releases.
Hardware schedule
We’re glad to say all production plans have been transferred towards the larger-volume plant in Romania. We have been working with them on the production schedule, trying to pull in where possible. Immediately after we had the first SmartScopes of the Early Bird batch passing the post-production tests, we ordered all PCBs to fulfill the outstanding orders. Since our KickStarter campaign was quite successful, the standard leadtime for such a quantity of was 25 working days. We decided to pay an extra fee, in order to have them finished in 17 working days instead, so after transportation they have  A first set of , and immediately after a positive validation the remainder of the batch will be produced.

With Early Bird packages flying all over the world, we’re glad to present you the new LabNation software to control the SmartScope!
As mentioned during our Kickstarter campaign, we believe that many of the USB scopes on the market run on software that is just required necessity to operate their hardware. While in reality, you will be dealing most of the time with the software. Therefore, we went the extra mile to provide you with an application which is calm, inviting, intuitive and easy to use.

Not yet actually, since there would be no-one to pick them up on Sunday. We packaged this first batch ourselves, consuming the largest part of the past two days. We scheduled a pick-up for tomorrow morning which will dispatch them around the world. Allowing one week of shipment, this means all Early Bird backers should have received their SmartScope by next Monday!

updates.update_userinfo: The Early Birds have left the building!
updates.update_content: As mentioned in our previous update, this week we joined our manufacturer for testing this batch of 100 SmartScopes. After our slip-up during the past batch we were a bit more modest, yet confident that our fix should have solved the issue. Nevertheless, the first devices we tested failed in a way similar to the ones of the last batch. Quite soon, it became clear the culprit was a capacitor that should not have been fitted. A mistake resulting from the rush order we placed during the yearly holiday of our manufacturer, requiring someone to manually tinker with our BOM.

And finally, for now: a feature sometimes found on serious bench 'scopes is pulse-width triggering: the trigger signal has to be above (or below) the threshold for a certain time before the sweep is triggered. This is very useful for catching packets of data, or any signal which comes in bursts.

The reason I suggested the JSON format (key/value data-pair as text) is it is one of the "leanest" of formats and is very amenable to compression. So for example, if you wish to "transmit" captured data to a host device via wifi, you may be able to pull it off if you could send compressed (JSAN) data :-) XML formats are not really lean :-(

Instead of using a third-party cloud service, how about just sending the data to a server (eg, (T)FTP) on the local (wireless) LAN? They are easy enough to set up - FileZilla, for example - and more advanced users can run an application that'll automagically catch the data and process or archive it.

Regarding the refresh rate, all oscilloscopes have a maximum trigger rate. 200 fps for a USB oscilloscope is extremely good. 2x 100MS/s, assuming 8-bit samples, is 1.6 Gbit/s! Even without allowing for processing and communication overheads that's way more than ordinary USB 2.0 can handle.

How is specifying 50MHz bandwidth @ 100MS/s misleading? The numbers are right there for you to interpret. Any signal that is sampled without aliasing can be accurately reconstructed with the correct interpolation (sin(x)/x for example). If linear interpolation is used exclusively then yes, there will be interpolation errors. In time domain applications, yes, it is desirable to be oversampled rather than simply meeting the nyquist criteria, but it is not strictly required. Of course the product will not have a brick wall 50MHz response and will incur some aliasing such that an exact representation even with ideal interpolation is possible, but this is a low cost oscilloscope. If you want a true time domain representation without interpolation you either pay lots of money for a high powered digitizing oscilloscope or buy an old analog oscilloscope and live without the nice features of a digitizing one.

Great project by the way. I'm sure you'll reach your goal quickly, and I'm looking forward to seeing the SmartScope in production.
Good luck guys with this project. At 10K already in one day I believe you took a great start.

Could you say something about how the triggering works? Can you set trigger level and rising/falling edges? Can you trigger the analogue inputs off one of the digital inputs? And do you still get 200fps with a trigger condition set?
3.) Do you plan any stretch goals (like upgrading the Spartan 3 to Spartan 6)?

campaign.story:
Project Description
Rigamo is a new mixed multi-media endeavor about a young superhero, Kera Moore. Kera is a young girl who accidentally stumbles upon a secret ability: her tears bring people back to life. However, there is one caveat: when she brings someone back to life, she ages by multiple years.
We start off the story with 6-year-old Kera who discovers that her goldfish has died. This is her first experience with death, and as she cries her tears fall into the fishbowl. 
Kera Age 6 (preliminary artwork)
The next day the fish is revived, but Kera wakes up to find herself 9 years old. Now that she's discovered her power, Kera must make a choice: should she use her power for the greater good even though there's a high probability that she will lose an unknown number of years of her own life?
Why This Project?
The Rigamo universe seamlessly spans both a short film called Rigamo and a comic book series based on Kera, the main character. The short film is to be written and directed by Che Grayson with special animation and visual effects done by Sharon De La Cruz. The art in the comic book is to be done by Sharon with a story written by Che. Our cumulative vision ensures that Rigamo will be an interesting, multifaceted project focused on promoting positive characters from under-represented communities whose stories deal with current social issues.
Through Rigamo, we want to promote positive images of young black girls in the visual mediums of both film and print media. We also wanted to dive into the more personal themes of mourning and healing within those Black and Latino communities.
We are experimenting with a storytelling experience in which we follow Kera Moore through the discovery of her newfound power which begins in a 6 minute film that ends on a cliffhanger and continues through volume 1 of the comic book. We hope you're down to join us for the ride!
Funding
We already have a full third of our budget in the form of a grant from NYU's Graduate Student Organization and are attempting to raise the rest with this Kickstarter campaign which will cover:
- Costumes and production design to help bring the vision to life
- Transportation for cast and crew
- Food for cast and crew
- Price of film stock and film development
- Pay for film festival submission fees so we can get this story to a greater audience. 
We really appreciate the time you've taken to read about our project and we hope that you are as excited as we are to work towards paving the way for a new black female superhero.
Rigamo is about pushing the boundaries of how we experience stories. Every little bit you can give us not only goes directly towards the film and comic, but will be the catalyst for a project that can expand and take a life of it's own. We'd love for you to be a part of our journey. If you can't donate, share with others any support at all will get us one step closer!
Lots of Love, 
Che and Sharon
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest challenge that the Rigamo project faces is the time constraint. Both the film and the comic must be presented at NYU by April 25th.

However, with your help in addition to the help of our fellow NYU collaborators we will be able to see this project through to fruition!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
We are trying to raise additional funds for the TFK Roadshow, a three week tour of Lesotho and South Africa to offer free and public screenings of our feature film THE FORGOTTEN KINGDOM. The film is about a wayward young man who reluctantly returns to his ancestral land of Lesotho to bury his father. It's the first film made in Lesotho, about the Basotho, and spoken in the native Sesotho language. It's won seven awards at international film festivals thus far, and is scheduled for theatrical release in South Africa in April 2014 (details for American release are still pending). For the trailer and more info, please go to our website - www.forgottenkingdomthemovie.com
The roadshow will begin with a gala premiere at the Ster-Kinekor cinema in Maseru on March 1st, and then we'll travel with the film to the Lesotho towns of Semonkong, Roma, Leribe, Mokhotlong, Morija, Mohale's Hoek, Malealea, Quthing, and more. Following Lesotho, we'll travel to the South African townships of Diepsloot and Soweto to screen the film there. In all of these locations, we'll show the film on a huge inflatable movie screen. Our mission is to share this story with as many people in Lesotho and South Africa possible. We'll be going off road, to remote mountain villages. Many of these people have never seen a film before, let alone one that's set in their own country, and told in their own language!
Our roadshow crew is made up of American, South African, and Basotho volunteers. Expenses include the renting of vehicles, screening gear (screen, projector, sound gear, tents, etc), food and lodging, travel costs, etc. Please support this cause by making a donation! This film is eagerly anticipated in southern Africa, and we're trying to make it the best homecoming possible…
For those of you who have already made a donation at one of our screenings, we thank you. For those who haven't, here's your chance!
Still reading? Here's more about the filmmaking team, and a list of the festivals and awards won so far.
Written and Directed by Andrew Mudge. Produced by T.R. Boyce Jr., Pieter Lombaard, Cecil Matlou, and Andrew Mudge. Executive Producers, Chris Roland and Terry Leonard. Producer of Marketing and Distribution, Ciara Lacy. Cinematography by Carlos Carvalho. Music by Robert Miller.
•Best Feature, Best Cinematography, Best Editing at the 2013 Woodstock Film Festival
•Audience Award, Sarasota Film Festival
•Audience Award, Cambridge Film Festival
•Audience Award, Florida Film Festival
•Audience Award, Ashland Independent Film Festival
•Audience Award, Woods Hole Film Festival
•Best Feature, Conscious Media Film Festival
•Best Feature, Port Townsend Film Festival
•Award Winner, Heartland Film Festival
•Official Selection, Palm Springs International Film Festival
•Official Selection, Seattle International Film Festival
•Official Selection, Durban International Film Festival
•Opening Night Film, Toronto Black Film Festival
•Official Selection, Detour Film Festival Venice Italy
•Official Selection, Montreal International Black Film Festival
•Official Selection, Berkshires Film Festival
•Official Selection, Pan African Film Festival
•Official Selection, Jozi Film Festival

updates.update_userinfo: The Forgotten Kingdom DVDs coming soon!

updates.update_content: Kickstarter supporters THANK YOU! We have exceeded our goal, and I'm presently in the mountains of Lesotho, having just finished our 6th roadshow screening. Despite some setbacks with the weather, it's been a great success so far. We've screened The Forgotten Kingdom in churches, fields, and along mountain roads - to audiences ranging from the King of Lesotho to herdboys who have never seen a television set before. The below photo was taken last night, about an hour before the screening began. It took us one hour on 4 wheel drive roads to reach this remote village where we filmed in 2011, and we ended up having about 200 villagers wrapped up in their blankets in front of our blow-up screen. They absolutely freaked out when they saw people and locations that they recognized. For more photos, please "like" our Facebook page. Thank you again!
Here's another one that didn't make the final cut. Enjoy!

updates.update_userinfo: Deleted Scene: Sello's Soliloquy part II
updates.update_content:
You did it folks! Your generosity brought us to our $6,500 goal and beyond. THANK YOU!
Now I'm going to add a zero to the end of that number, and ask each of you to donate ten times your amount - that way we can finally buy the TFK helicopter and hovercraft package I've always dreamed about. Kidding! We have just the right amount now to pay for vehicle rentals, petrol, hotel accommodation, salaries, equipment rentals, and a few police bribes here and there. All funds we receive over the target amount goes to paying off our music rights, so that's nice too.

This one minute sequence was the original opening to the film. It was my intention that I would bookend the first part of the movie with this these lyrical allegories from the shepherd boy called Sello. These images were strongly inspired by Paulo Coehlo's The Alchemist, and were the first ones that came to me when I was conceiving the idea for The Forgotten Kingdom. In the end, we decided that it slowed the film down too much, so it was all removed.  It's sweetly ironic to me that the very images that inspired the making of the film ultimately didn't make the cut. As we often learn in the editing room, "Kill your darlings!"

campaign.story:
Welcome to my KICKSTARTER campaign.  My name is Heather Weston.  I am a photographer living in New York City. The idea for AT HOME came together out of living in a 450 square foot apartment with my family in Brooklyn.  I became intrigued by how other people were doing it. How were they living in their apartments, brownstones, houses? How were they using their space?
I quickly began to formulate the idea of visiting people. Acquaintances, close friends, family members and creating a photographic portrait essay with people I know living together as a family.  My plan was to visit one family every week for the whole year! 52 weeks equals 52 families. I completed the task and recorded my results along the way on my blog.
The images from AT HOME were all taken in 2011.  Now in March 2014, I have the opportunity to exhibit this work at the Invisible Dog's Glass House in Brooklyn, New York.  
AT HOME is about connecting people and exploring the spaces in which we all live.  I have some great rewards for all you supporters. The funds raised will be used for printing and framing as many images from the year as possible. Other expenses include preparing the space, hanging the work and promotional materials involved in an exhibition.
REWARDS - A few images from the Heather Weston Greeting Card Collection.
The AT HOME show TOTE!  Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
campaign.risks:

updates.update_content:
Hey Supporters, 
I wanted to share with you some links to the press we have received since the show has gone up. I am so pleased with the positive attention the show has been getting. It is hard to believe we are down to the last two weeks that the show will be up!
By now most of you should have received your rewards. It was real fun putting the packages together with my mom while she was in town.  The posters have arrived so if you are one of the poster supporters you will be receiving your packages next week. Thank you!

Sorry I have not been in touch. As soon as we were good to go and the project was funded I went into show overdrive. This past week has been insane! Fun but crazed. I made some new friends over at Printspace, David and Caroline, who helped me get 47 images printed. I just picked up the last few tonight. Prints. Done!
Prepping the Glass House, assembling the frames and installing the images has been full on. The big kicker is The Glass House is NOT insulated. I am soooo cold my bones are numb.  I really wanted to take some behind the scenes insta pics to share with you all but we were so busy I forgot to record our moments. I can also report that Rachel Godsil braced the chill and helped to assemble many a frame. Thank you Rachel! I hired this great guy Joseph Lucas from ICP for the installation and it has been a pleasure to get to know him. He is a transplant from California and a Marine Brat, how weird is that? If you did not know this already I am from California and a marine brat too.  We are finishing the installation tomorrow.

Thank you all so much. I did not expect to reach this goal so early on in the campaign. Thanks to all of you for jumping on board so soon.  We have hit the minimum mark to get funded!     
I have started work on printing samples, getting invites and promotional materials ready, measuring the space and trying not to freak out.
I will continue to send out word about this AT HOME kickstarter campaign and hopefully we can get that number up to cover more costs.  Please continue to share with your networks too.

Thank you so much for taking the time and investment to help with this photographic essay. I am so grateful to all of you for making this 1st week such a success. I have been posting and sending out emails and many of you have been sharing the link and getting the word out and THANK YOU for that too!  I love an exclamation point and you and this week deserve many many exclamation points from me!!!!!!!!!!! 
I have been pulling together all the images and getting ready to send off that big print order for when we reach the first number I hope to get to and that is $6500. Please keep sharing with your networks of art lovers and lets see if we can pass that first goal.

comments.content: Candra

Hey Heather! I got my hands on this campaign through Erica, and I'm so glad she shared it! I'm currently living in a 10x12ft room in a foreign country, I can't tell you how much this speaks to me, and how inspiring it is to know that we can transform our nagging misgivings into something fresh through art. Thank you for doing this!

campaign.story:
What is Rocks & Gravel Coffee?
Rocks & Gravel Coffee is a local, organic Full City Roast, shipped direct from our roaster, in recyclable, collectible coffee tins. It tastes great and gives back! 
"It takes rocks and gravel, baby... to make a solid road" – Bob Dylan
What is our plan?
Our vision at R&G is to build our membership of coffee drinkers, by selling limited edition coffee tins and having refill coffee sent fresh and direct from the roaster to your door. Our goal of $20,000 on Kickstarter will give us the resources to:
Print first batch labels, tins, stickers, T-shirts and Mugs
Roast the first batch of delicious coffee and send it out to you
Pay our talented artist, web designer and videographer
Custom build a Rocks & Gravel Coffee cart for pour over (Chemex) coffee
Set up our office and put systems in place for customer service
What is our product?
We like to keep it simple. We have one roast to start with. We have chosen a Full City Roast, which is in between a medium and dark roast, perfect when prepared as a pour over (Chemex) or as a cold brew. Our coffee is also delicious as espresso or any way you like it. 
There are two ways to order it:
Limited edition collectible tins (12 OZ) for $18.99
Discount refills (10 OZ) for just $11.99
Our bean in a recyclable tin, fresh from the roaster
Why is our coffee so delicious?
Most coffees today are roasted too long and become burnt and bitter. Our beans are wet washed and sun dried to minimize toxins, offering coffee drinkers a clean caffeine high with no jittery feelings. 
Our Full City roast
Our roaster doesn't burn the bean, which is what happens with a French roast or higher. Instead, our Full City Roast has the right balance of bite and aroma, bold and chocolatey with a smooth and smoky flavor. Great for pour over single cup or in the Chemex for multiple cup brews.
Full of natural oils and anti-oxidants
Here's some nerdy facts about our bean:
Cooperative:  La Florida Cooperativa
Certifications:  Fair Trade, Smithsonian Bird Friendly
Region:  The Chanchamayo province in the Junin region of Central Peru
Altitude:  1,200 – 1,400 meters
Variety: Bourbon, Catimor, Typica, Caturra, and Pache
Harvest: March – August
Our clean beans before the roast
 How does our coffee give back?
Our coffee give back in four main ways:
Planet friendly – our packaging is 100% recyclable and reusable
Community & animal friendly – our coffee beans are fair trade, USDA certified organic, 'bird friendly' and shade grown
Customer friendly – Rocks & Gravel Members get $1 off their next coffee tin order when they refer a friend
Artist friendly – our artist, Stef Mitchell, receives a royalty for every tin sold
What do you get if you make a pledge today?
Any pledge amount counts. Find the one that best suits you. Get started with a Limited Edition Pledge Tin or join the R&G Crew with a quarterly or yearly membership! 
We hope that you will get involved and become part of the R&G crew, by making a pledge to get a whole year's supply of fresh coffee for just $250. Annual membership comes complete with three different limited edition tins and nine additional monthly refills. On top of that we will gift you a Rocks & Gravel T-shirt, limited edition Mug and Pour Over Cup. We think it is a killer deal! 
What are our most popular kinds of pledges?
'Pledge' Edition R&G Coffee Tin (12 OZ) - $25 - limited edition signed collectible tin of R&G coffee (shipping incl.) 
3 month membership - $100 - 1 tin + 2 months of refills (comes with a free Pour Over Cup) (shipping incl.) 
1 year membership - $350 - 3 tins + 9 months of refills (plus a free R&G T-shirt, Mug, & Pour Over Cup) (shipping incl.) 
For memberships: Our gift of a Pour Over Mug for single cup brews
Prototype R&G limited edition Boarder T-shirt
Prototype R&G Limited Edition Bear Mug
What are some special pledge rewards?
If you like 'dream catchers' our chief of communications Sophie Ward will hand make you one for just $75. It will come with your first specialty R&G coffee tin.
If you are a Kin fan, you can pledge $10 and receive a limited edition cover EP by Isaac and Thorald Koren of The Kin with an R&G collectible sticker. If you are even more of a Kin fan, you can pledge $1500, receive a yearly R&G membership, and enjoy your very own 'Musical Robbery' by The Kin in NYC. 
If you are a big fan of our artist, Stef Mitchell, you can pledge $750 to receive your own original full size Stef Mitchell original artwork. This last pledge comes with a full yearly R&G membership.
For the big spenders, we have the option of your own private 'Salon Dinner Party' event hosted by our team for a pledge of $2500 or higher.
Why do we want to make a coffee cart?
We intend to build our own wooden coffee cart for pour over coffee, so we can bring R&G coffee to the streets! This will fit two people, one to measure, grind and prepare the individual pour over cups of delicious coffee, and one person to handle the customers. 
The cart will tweet its location @rocksandgravel and will also travel to music festivals, cycling races, local markets and busy street corners. We think it is a unique cart in that it is focused on pour over coffee and offers a freshly brewed cup of coffee to every customer.
Prototype Pour Over Coffee Cart
Reclaimed wood Pour Over Bar for the cart
What is our story? 
Rocks & Gravel Coffee began last year while I was cycling along the Delaware river with my brother and partner in crime, Thorald Koren. 
On our ride we stumbled across a local organic coffee roaster. After meeting the two brothers who run the roaster, we began discussing the possibility of bringing to life a coffee that tastes great and also gives back. 
In collaboration with artist Stef Mitchell, we designed a tin that is both collectible, reusable and gives back both locally and globally. 
Will you help us build a solid road?
None of this can happen without you. Our goal is to raise $20,000 to produce the first batch of coffee and tins, pay our wonderful artist, build the website, and send our product to your door. Check out our pledges below to join the Rocks & Gravel crew.
                                                 THANK YOU!
Founder, Isaac Koren
Brand Director, Thorald Koren
Artist, Stef Mitchell
Chief of Communications, Sophie Ward
Product Manager, Ashley Maher
Business Development, Georgina Koren
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are many challenges that face new businesses:

HOW RELIABLE IS THE SUPPLY?
We have made sure that we have a solid relationship with our local roaster so that we can guarantee delivery of fresh coffee to our drinkers. Our importer has solid working relationships and we look to pass on the benefits to you.

HOW DO WE KNOW IT TASTES GREAT, ALWAYS? 
We have tested our roast on a large group of friends and family and coffee connoisseurs and the response has been very positive, so we are confident in how the coffee tastes, especially when prepared as a 'pour over' or as a 'cold brew'. Our Full City Roast is best and most pure when prepared in a 'pour over' set, so that is why we include a pour over set in both the 3 month and yearly membership pledges.

HOW IS YOUR CUSTOMER SERVICE?
Our team, the Rocks & Gravel Crew, are fully engaged to make customer service both personal and enjoyable. Coffee is about play and good work relies on it.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The Neck is a Bridge to the Body is a new kind of guitar exploration with live music and video projection. What sets this show apart is that for the first time the guitar itself is being used as a projection screen. The show opens as a creation story where the notes and sounds create the images. It then broadens into an exploration of the guitar where we learn that it is shape shifter, it has travelled all over the world, it has a background with friends and family, and it even has an internal skeleton and nervous system. Finally, we see that music creates the musician, and the guitar creates the guitarist.
I need you to help me and visual arts company, Glowing Pictures, produce the debut show, which will happen at BRIC House in Brooklyn, NY, on March 6, and to build something that I can take on the road and share with you all.
One of the things I've tried to do in my career as a guitarist is to push the limits of the guitar far beyond what is expected. I'm always employing new techniques, tunings, and approaches in order to coax out sounds that haven't been heard before. This show is an extension and exploration of that philosophy. If the guitar can show any picture or wear any kind of skin then how will I relate to it as an instrument that I'm so comfortable with, and is it possible for an audience to see such a familiar object in an entirely new way? Those are the questions that The Neck tries to answer.
All the images you will see in this show will be original, from the digital creations and animations that Glowing Pictures invents, to videos and movies that we will produce ourselves. This takes an enormous amount of time and effort, and your help will go towards hiring the best team possible and making sure that everyone can spend all the time they need on achieving the most artistic result.
This project has required me to write all new music to play live, and we want to record an album of the soundtrack to accompany the show. This will involve all of the usual costs of making and mastering an album, and your contribution will help greatly here.
Here are some of the pieces of equipment we will need to purchase:
HD projectors
mapping software
still/video camera
custom large screen with portable stands
dedicated computer to run the software
custom guitar effects pedal to control sound of the guitar
HDMI cables and equipment stands
Thank you so much for taking the time to watch this video and read through this page.  I think this project has incredible potential and I'm so excited to get started.  Feel free to ask any questions you have about the project or the rewards.  I appreciate your support so much and I can't wait to share this project with you!
Love, Kaki
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Whenever you have to create original visuals and movies there are always expensive production costs and lengthy time frames to consider. I also want to make sure that the artists are compensated for their original work.

Getting this show on the road presents its own challenges. A custom screen needs to be built, equipment needs to be bought, and a professional team needs to be trained.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
1000.times { puts "Thank you!" }
Feb 22 2014 
You are all amazing. Thank you so much for your support.
Hello Ruby wouldn't have happened without you all. It started as my sideproject, but grew into something so much bigger.
The campaign is now over and this page is frozen. You can see everything that happened in the campaign - but it is all out of date and you can't back the project anymore. If you're interested in Ruby's world, or want to pre-order the book, head over to www.helloruby.com. I'll be waiting you over!
Hugs,
- Linda
--
And here’s the story that started it all:
My name is Linda Liukas. I have spent the last three years teaching programming and making the world of technology more approachable for the millions through co-founding a non-profit called Rails Girls and working at Codecademy.
Now, I want to combine software with storytelling. I want to write and illustrate a book for young children about the magical world of technology - Hello Ruby. 
Twitter: @lindaliukas  
Blog: http://helloruby.com
----
UPGRADES: EVERYONE who has pledged for the first hardcover book or above will ALSO get a digital version of the book and workbook.
STRETCH-GOAL 250 000: If we hit 250 000, I'll write a Parents Guide to complement the workbook and make it available as a download.
STRETCH-GOAL 500 000: If we hit 500 000, I'll extend Ruby's world into a mobile app. Think magic!
---
As seen on
Hello Ruby kids' coding book raises $185k (and counting) on Kickstarter. (27.1.2014)
Kickstarter loves this children's book that gets kids excited about coding (23.1.2014)
Can this children's book help make the Internet a better place? (29.1.2014) 
Children's book Hello Ruby teaches 4 to 7 year olds how to code  (28.1.2014)
 Book That Teaches Kids to Code raises 250k on Kickstarter (4.2.2014)
 Getting Girls Into Programming, One Children's Book At A Time (4.2.2014)
The story
Ruby is a small girl with a huge imagination. She stomps and stumbles around her own little world while her dad is traveling. On her adventures, Ruby makes friends with the lonely Snow Leopard, visits castles made of windows, and solves problems with the wise penguins. She bakes gingerbreads with the green robots and throws a garden party with... well, if you like to hear the rest of the story, I need your help.
Ruby's world is an extension of the way I've learned to see technology. It goes far beyond the bits and bytes inside the computer. This is the story of what happens between the ones and zeros, before the arrays and the if/else statements. The book and workbook are aimed for four to seven year olds. 
I believe stories are the most formative force of our childhood. Everyone has a book that made the world seem beautiful and full of possibility. My book is about little Ruby.
Ruby and her friends
Why this matters?
Code is the 21st century literacy and the need for people to speak the ABC of Programming is imminent. Our world is increasingly run by software and we need more diversity in the people who are building it.
More importantly, writing software is about expression, creativity - and practical application. Our kids should learn to bend, join, break and combine code in a way it wasn't designed to. Just as they would with crayons and paper or wood and tools. I believe there's plenty to learn in programming logic and culture before showing children a single screen.
Here's what I want to do
 Hello Ruby is a children's book that comes with an activity book. The two books teach the very foundations of technology through stories and activities that serve as a simple template for all future learning. The book and workbook are aimed for four to seven year olds. 
Why a storybook?
 We all have treasured childhood stories that have affected the way we see reality. Instead of only focusing on how applications are built or code is constructed, I want to tell about the architects, principles and personalities behind software. And I believe the best way to tell this story is through a book that will be read with children and parents at night, and live in the bookshelf for years to come.
Hello Ruby will be a classic journey of discovery that teaches the readers about different people working together, how problems can be solved in small sequences and how remixing and sharing helps everyone.
Illustrations are as important as the story. My book will be full of detail and whimsy, with cutaways and magical moments, a world where everything is not apparent at once.
Hardcover book, 8 x 8 inches and 32 pages 
Traditional story of friendship, being different .. and technology. 
Why an activity book?
The activity book teaches kids early programming skills. It’s designed to be enjoyed by a kid alone, but can also be worked through with an adult. And best of all - the workbook is designed to be doodled, wrecked and drawn all over. 
The foundational knowledge structures, like sequences, variables, patterns, loops, lists, conditionals, operators and events. Taught through exercises of dot-to-dot, pairs, odd-one-out, all from Ruby's world. 
A sprinkle of software culture, by teaching them to abstract and modularise, work iteratively and incrementally as well as encouraging them to reuse and remix work. 
Creativity and DIY attitude. Tons of doodles, logic puzzles and even a foldable miniature laptop that allows the kid to peek inside a computer. 
The Budget
The book will be hardcover, 8x8 inches and 32 pages. The activity book is  16 pages and paperback. To make the minimum order of 1000 copies, I need you.
You'll get a lovely old-fashioned storybook that introduces Ruby and the other characters. In addition there will be a workbook with puzzles, exercises and additional materials for the parent to teach web literature for the little ones. 
I'm writing and illustrating all of this myself. Most of the funds will be production costs: printing the books and workbooks and hiring an editor. And you'll get to be a part of the journey of a first time author. 
Breakdown of budget
Editor for spelling and storyline
Purchase of fonts
Book and workbook layout design
Obtaining ISBN numbers, registration fees and costs associated with getting listed in online bookstores
Production of the books 
Shipping 
Who am I?
Prior to writing this book, I co-founded Rails Girls, a global non-profit teaching programming to tens of thousands of women in over 160 cities. I also worked at Codecademy as one of the first employees. I first got excited about programming when I was 13 years old and madly in love with Al Gore. However, it took me almost ten years to learn more than the basics, so beginners are close to my heart. 
I'm a Ruby Hero 2013 and the Digital Champion of Finland. 
See my talk at Heroku Waza 2013 on Ruby and a talk on girls & programming in Railsberry 2012. 
Tell me more about Ruby!
 Gladly. I've actually already drawn a few of her adventures here.
Ruby is one of the best little girls I know.  
She has family all around the world. Her father is from Japan, but she has aunts and uncles and siblings and cousins everywhere.  Ruby loves her family, wants to be helpful and make people around her happy. 
Sometimes Ruby is a little bossy. She says things like “Get me the milk from the lowest shelf of the fridge” and “Combine two spoonfuls of cocoa with the milk”. 
Ruby learns quickly. If you show her how to make her bed, she’ll have no trouble doing it a hundred times over. 
And she’s independent: Ruby doesn’t like other people telling her how to clean her room, only what should be done, while she prefers to figure out the process herself. 
All the adults say Ruby is a sensible, nice kid. But sometimes she can be mischievous. If you’re not very precise in ordering your chocolate, the kitchen might end up be flooding with hot cocoa. 
Ruby’s favorite things in the world are her precious gems. The colorful, glittering gemstones are presents from all over the world. When Ruby closes her eyes the gems become magic and help her do things she never could have done alone. 
Ruby's friends are pretty mischievous too. Androids are messy. Snowleopard doesn't want to play with other kids. Penguins are booksmart but sometimes hard to understand. 
Oh, and the coolest thing about Ruby? She and her friends have their own secret language. Can you guess what happens when Ruby says: 
  puts “hip hip hooray “*5
In Ruby’s world there are words that mean things and words that do things. And magic happens every day.
Past updates
Fri Jan 24, 2014
Oh wow. What a day.
You are amazing. During the first 24 hours of the campaign we surpassed $100k. I'm so excited to be able to work on Ruby's world with all of this overwhelming support.
Every additional dollar will go towards building the magical world of Ruby. A larger budget means I can commit to making everything so much more better. Let’s do this! Thank you so much for your support.
Hugs,
- Linda
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I’ve spent the last weeks learning everything I can about authoring, publishing and printing. The timelines for printing and shipping something this big are very different from the project I started with. It’s all very exciting, but also all very new. Luckily I have great people helping me. 

I know it sucks to wait for more than 6 months for a book, but for normal industry printed books the cycle is even longer. Here's my plan: 

1. Making the book 
This is the first time I’m doing a children's book. I’ve talked with several Kickstarter authors about the process as well as other children's book authors. I've almost written the story and sketched the pages into a storyboard format. Before starting with the final artwork, I'd like to hire a native english speaking editor to go through the story with me. With all of the support I can also work together with an art director. I hope you’ll love every single page of both books as I've loved making them. 

2. Printing the book
 When the book leaves my desk, there’s still a lot of things that need to happen. My biggest concern is the shipping, but also printing takes time. 

Both the storybook and the workbook are industry standard, so production problems shouldn't be an issue. Now that the Kickstarter is ending, I'll know the number of books I can afford and where I should be printing them. 

3) Shipping the book
Shipping is expensive and always a bit of an unknown. This is why I’m planning on shipping the books with Amazon and using their third party fulfilment services. If there are delays in shipping I’ll keep everyone posted and try to share the e-book (as that’s the one part I really can influence) as soon as possible with all the backers (excluding the 5 dollar pledge category). 

I’m very committed to making this all happen and feel very privileged by all the support. I will keep you posted, all the way.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
